message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Collaborative Multi-Robot Search and Rescue: Planning, Coordination, Perception, and Active Vision
Paper Abstract: Search and rescue (SAR) operations can take significant advantage from supporting autonomous or teleoperated robots and multi-robot systems. These can aid in mapping and situational assessment, monitoring and surveillance, establishing communication networks, or searching for victims. This paper provides a review of multi-robot systems supporting SAR operations, with system-level considerations and focusing on the algorithmic perspectives for multi-robot coordination and perception. This is, to the best of our knowledge, the first survey paper to cover (i) heterogeneous SAR robots in different environments, (ii) active perception in multi-robot systems, while (iii) giving two complementary points of view from the multi-agent perception and control perspectives. We also discuss the most significant open research questions: shared autonomy, sim-to-real transferability of existing methods, awareness of victims' conditions, coordination and interoperability in heterogeneous multi-robot systems, and active perception. The different topics in the survey are put in the context of the different challenges and constraints that various types of robots (ground, aerial, surface, or underwater) encounter in different SAR environments (maritime, urban, wilderness, or other post-disaster scenarios). The objective of this survey is to serve as an entry point to the various aspects of multi-robot SAR systems to researchers in both the machine learning and control fields by giving a global overview of the main approaches being taken in the SAR robotics area.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what active vision is:

## Active Vision

Active vision, also called active computer vision, is an area of computer vision where a system can manipulate the viewpoint of camera(s) in order to investigate the environment and get better information from it.

### Key Advantages

Active vision is particularly important for coping with problems like occlusions, limited field of view, and limited resolution of the camera.(no content)Other advantages include reducing motion blur of moving objects and enhancing depth perception by focusing multiple cameras on the same object or moving the cameras.

### Historical Context

Beginning in the late 1980s, Aloimonos et al. introduced the first general framework for active vision to improve the perceptual quality of tracking results.

### Connection to Biological Vision

The selective aspect of active vision is related to visual attention in biological organisms, which enhances perception of selected parts of the visual field.

### Applications

Examples of active vision applications include vehicle tracking, robotics applications, and interactive MRI segmentation.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Multi-robot system"

Links: [{"title":"Category:Multi-robot systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-robot_systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-robot_systems"},{"title":"Figure AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Figure_AI"},{"title":"Asynchronous multi-body framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asynchronous_multi-body_framework"},{"title":"Robot 17 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_17"}]

Here are the search results for "Multi-robot system":

## Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents, which can include robots. Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system have important characteristics including autonomy (agents are at least partially independent and self-aware) and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).(no content)These systems also tend to prevent propagation of faults, self-recover and be fault tolerant, mainly due to the redundancy of components.

## Communication and Components

When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language, such as Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL), within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, the approach may lead to a common improvement.

## Applications

Multi-agent systems present possible applications in microrobotics, where the physical interaction between the agents are exploited to perform complex tasks such as manipulation and assembly of passive components.

The search results also included information about simulation frameworks like AMBF that support multi-robot environments and specific examples of multi-robot coordination, such as Figure AI's Helix system.

Web search results for query: "Robot navigation"

Links: [{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Category:Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Robotic mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_mapping"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"},{"title":"Simultaneous localization and mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simultaneous_localization_and_mapping"},{"title":"Automated guided vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_guided_vehicle"},{"title":"Evolution Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_Robotics"},{"title":"Distributed architecture for mobile navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_architecture_for_mobile_navigation"},{"title":"Layered costmaps - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Layered_costmaps"},{"title":"AVM Navigator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AVM_Navigator"}]

I've successfully searched for information on robot navigation. Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Robot navigation means the robot's ability to determine its own position in its frame of reference and then to plan a path towards some goal location.(no content)In order to navigate in its environment, the robot or any other mobility device requires representation, i.e. a map of the environment and the ability to interpret that representation.

## Types of Mobile Robots

Mobile robots can be "autonomous" (AMR - autonomous mobile robot) which means they are capable of navigating an uncontrolled environment without the need for physical or electro-mechanical guidance devices. Alternatively, an automated guided vehicle (AGV) is a portable robot that follows along marked long lines or wires on the floor, or uses radio waves, vision cameras, magnets, or lasers for navigation.

## Navigation Techniques

Several methods are used for robot navigation:

- Vision-based navigation uses computer vision algorithms and optical sensors, including laser-based range finder and photometric cameras, to extract the visual features required for localization in the surrounding environment.
- Some robot navigation systems use simultaneous localization and mapping to generate 3D reconstructions of their surroundings.
- Simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) is the computational problem of constructing or updating a map of an unknown environment while simultaneously keeping track of an agent's location within it.

## Applications

Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years. Warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"},{"title":"Autonomous robot architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot_architecture"},{"title":"Lethal autonomous weapon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lethal_autonomous_weapon"},{"title":"Denning Mobile Robot Company - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_research_robot"},{"title":"Delivery robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delivery_robot"},{"title":"Energetically Autonomous Tactical Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energetically_Autonomous_Tactical_Robot"},{"title":"Autonomous (novel) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_(novel)"},{"title":"Avride - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avride"},{"title":"List of robotics companies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_robotics_companies"},{"title":"Autonomous Robotics Ltd - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Robotics_Ltd"}]

## Search Results for "Autonomous robot"

I've found comprehensive information about autonomous robots. Here's a summary of the key findings:

### Definition and Basic Concept

An autonomous robot is a robot that acts without recourse to human control.(no content)Historic examples include space probes, while modern examples include self-driving vacuums and cars.

### Common Applications

**Domestic Use:**
A new area showing commercial promise is domestic robots, with a flood of small vacuuming robots beginning with iRobot and Electrolux in 2002.

**Delivery Services:**
A delivery robot is an autonomous robot that provides "last mile" delivery services.(no content)Companies actively delivering include Starship Technologies, which by June 2023 had completed over 5 million commercial autonomous deliveries with their fleet of 2,000 autonomous robots.

**Security and Monitoring:**
Amazon launched its Astro for home monitoring, security and eldercare in September 2021.

### Key Technologies

**Sensors and Perception:**
Autonomous robots must have a range of environmental sensors to perform their task and stay out of trouble.(no content)The most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation.

**Navigation:**
Current commercial robots autonomously navigate based on sensing natural features, with the first commercial robots to achieve this being Pyxus' HelpMate hospital robot and the CyberMotion guard robot, both designed by robotics pioneers in the 1980s.

The search results cover various aspects of autonomous robots including their development, current applications, underlying technologies, and future prospects.

## Search Results for "Autonomous robot"

I've found comprehensive information about autonomous robots. Here's a summary of the key findings:

### Definition and Basic Concept

An autonomous robot is a robot that acts without recourse to human control.(no content)Historic examples include space probes, while modern examples include self-driving vacuums and cars.

### Common Applications

**Domestic Use:**
A new area showing commercial promise is domestic robots, with a flood of small vacuuming robots beginning with iRobot and Electrolux in 2002.

**Delivery Services:**
A delivery robot is an autonomous robot that provides "last mile" delivery services.(no content)Companies actively delivering include Starship Technologies, which by June 2023 had completed over 5 million commercial autonomous deliveries with their fleet of 2,000 autonomous robots.

**Security and Monitoring:**
Amazon launched its Astro for home monitoring, security and eldercare in September 2021.

### Key Technologies

**Sensors and Perception:**
Autonomous robots must have a range of environmental sensors to perform their task and stay out of trouble.(no content)The most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation.

**Navigation:**
Current commercial robots autonomously navigate based on sensing natural features, with the first commercial robots to achieve this being Pyxus' HelpMate hospital robot and the CyberMotion guard robot, both designed by robotics pioneers in the 1980s.

The search results cover various aspects of autonomous robots including their development, current applications, underlying technologies, and future prospects.

Web search results for query: "Search and rescue"

Links: [{"title":"Search and rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_and_rescue"},{"title":"RAF Search and Rescue Force - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RAF_Search_and_Rescue_Force"},{"title":"Combat search and rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combat_search_and_rescue"},{"title":"Urban search and rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urban_search_and_rescue"},{"title":"Mounted search and rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mounted_search_and_rescue"},{"title":"National Search and Rescue Agency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Search_and_Rescue_Agency"},{"title":"Search and rescue dog - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_and_rescue_dog"},{"title":"National Association for Search and Rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Association_for_Search_and_Rescue"},{"title":"Storm Search and Rescue Tactical Vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Storm_Search_and_Rescue_Tactical_Vehicle"},{"title":"Canadian Armed Forces Search and Rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_Armed_Forces_Search_and_Rescue"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about search and rescue:

## Overview

Search and rescue (SAR) is the search for and provision of aid to people who are in distress or imminent danger.(no content)The general field of search and rescue includes many specialty sub-fields, typically determined by the type of terrain the search is conducted over.

## Main Types of Search and Rescue

**Urban Search and Rescue**: Urban search and rescue (abbreviated as USAR or US&R) is a type of technical rescue operation that involves the location, extrication, and initial medical stabilization of victims trapped in an urban area, namely structural collapse due to natural disasters, war, terrorism or accidents, mines and collapsed trenches.

**Combat Search and Rescue**: Combat search and rescue (CSAR) are search and rescue operations that are carried out during war that are within or near combat zones.

**Specialized Operations**: Search and rescue agencies may contain small specialist teams for executing operations where there are specific environmental risks. Examples include swift water rescue, flood response, technical rope rescue, confined space rescue, over-snow rescue, and thin ice rescue.

## Search and Rescue Resources

**Dogs**: A search-and-rescue (SAR) dog is a dog trained to respond to crime scenes, accidents, missing persons events, as well as natural or man-made disasters.

**Horses**: Mounted search and rescue (MSAR) is a specialty within search and rescue (SAR), using horses as search partners and for transportation to search for missing persons.

## Historical Context

On 29 November 1945, a Sikorsky R-5 performed the first civilian helicopter rescue operation in history, with Sikorsky's chief pilot Dmitry "Jimmy" Viner in the cockpit, using an experimental hoist developed jointly by Sikorsky and Breeze. All five crew members of an oil barge, which had run aground on Penfield Reef, were saved before the barge sank.

Based on the web search results, I found a reference to "shared autonomy" in the context of robotics. Here's what I found:

Shared autonomy is a concept in robotics research that has been applied to intelligent wheelchairs and other applications. The term appears in the context of robotics and assistive technology development.

Additionally, in a broader context, shared decision-making can refer to decision-support systems that make recommendations for human decision-makers to act on, sometimes known as augmented intelligence or 'shared decision-making'. This represents a collaborative approach where technology and humans work together in decision-making processes.

The search results also reference connected and automated mobility (CAM), which involves autonomous vehicles such as self-driving cars that can range from level 0 (complete human driving) to level 5 (completely autonomous), suggesting that varying degrees of shared control between humans and autonomous systems exist across different technologies.

Would you like me to search for more specific information about shared autonomy in a particular field, such as robotics, autonomous vehicles, or medical applications?

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous underwater vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_underwater_vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned underwater vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Underwater_robotics"},{"title":"Indian Underwater Robotics Society - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Underwater_Robotics_Society"},{"title":"Bluefin Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bluefin_Robotics"},{"title":"Talk:Indian Underwater Robotics Society - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Indian_Underwater_Robotics_Society"},{"title":"Carl Hayden High School - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Hayden_High_School"},{"title":"Bluefin-21 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bluefin-21"},{"title":"Spare Parts (2015 film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spare_Parts_(2015_film)"},{"title":"Underwater Dreams - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Underwater_Dreams"},{"title":"Atlantis ROV Team - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlantis_ROV_Team"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of underwater robotics based on the search results:

## What is Underwater Robotics?

Unmanned underwater vehicles (UUV), also known as underwater drones, are submersible vehicles that can operate underwater without a human occupant.(no content)These vehicles may be divided into two categories: remotely operated underwater vehicles (ROUVs) and autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs).

## Types of Underwater Vehicles

**Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs):** An autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) is a robot that travels underwater without requiring continuous input from an operator.(no content)AUVs are automated and operate independently of direct human input.

**Remotely Operated Underwater Vehicles (ROVs):** ROUVs are remotely controlled by a human operator.(no content)In addition to a camera, actuators, and sensors, ROUVs often include a 'gripper' or something to grasp objects with.

## Applications and Uses

The use of uncrewed Underwater Vehicles has risen consistently since they were introduced in the 1960s, and find their most frequent use in scientific research and data collection. Applications include mine countermeasures, surveillance, infrastructure inspection, and marine exploration. The REMUS is a three-foot long robot used to clear mines in one square mile within 16 hours, which is much more efficient, as a team of human divers would need upwards of 21 days to perform the same task.

## Notable Examples

Bluefin Robotics is an American robotics company, headquartered in Quincy, Massachusetts, which specialises in the design and manufacture of military and civilian autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) and related technology.(no content)The Bluefin-21 found its most famous use in April 2014 in the search for the wreckage of the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

Here's a comprehensive overview of underwater robotics based on the search results:

## What is Underwater Robotics?

Unmanned underwater vehicles (UUV), also known as underwater drones, are submersible vehicles that can operate underwater without a human occupant.(no content)These vehicles may be divided into two categories: remotely operated underwater vehicles (ROUVs) and autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs).

## Types of Underwater Vehicles

**Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs):** An autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) is a robot that travels underwater without requiring continuous input from an operator.(no content)AUVs are automated and operate independently of direct human input.

**Remotely Operated Underwater Vehicles (ROVs):** ROUVs are remotely controlled by a human operator.(no content)In addition to a camera, actuators, and sensors, ROUVs often include a 'gripper' or something to grasp objects with.

## Applications and Uses

The use of uncrewed Underwater Vehicles has risen consistently since they were introduced in the 1960s, and find their most frequent use in scientific research and data collection. Applications include mine countermeasures, surveillance, infrastructure inspection, and marine exploration. The REMUS is a three-foot long robot used to clear mines in one square mile within 16 hours, which is much more efficient, as a team of human divers would need upwards of 21 days to perform the same task.

## Notable Examples

Bluefin Robotics is an American robotics company, headquartered in Quincy, Massachusetts, which specialises in the design and manufacture of military and civilian autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) and related technology.(no content)The Bluefin-21 found its most famous use in April 2014 in the search for the wreckage of the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

Web search results for query: "Drone robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Autel Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autel_Robotics"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Lethal autonomous weapon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lethal_autonomous_weapon"},{"title":"Lily Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lily_Robotics"},{"title":"THeMIS - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/THeMIS"},{"title":"3D Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3D_Robotics"},{"title":"International Aerial Robotics Competition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Aerial_Robotics_Competition"},{"title":"RoboBee - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RoboBee"},{"title":"Unmanned ground vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_ground_vehicle"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of drone robotics:

## Definition and Basics

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## History and Development

UAVs were originally developed through the twentieth century for military missions too "dull, dirty or dangerous" for humans, and by the twenty-first, they had become essential assets to most militaries.(no content)As control technologies improved and costs fell, their use expanded to many non-military applications including aerial photography, area coverage, precision agriculture, forest fire monitoring, river monitoring, environmental monitoring, weather observation, policing and surveillance, infrastructure inspections, smuggling, product deliveries, entertainment and drone racing.

## Market Overview

In 2025, Chinese drone companies held 90% of the global UAV market share, with DJI accounting 80 percent of the world market. Other manufacturers include 3D Robotics, Yuneec, Autel Robotics, and Parrot.

## Advanced Applications

**Swarm Robotics:** Drone swarms are used in target search, drone displays, and delivery, with drone displays commonly using multiple, lighted drones at night for artistic displays or advertising, and delivery drone swarms capable of carrying multiple packages to a single destination and overcoming a single drone's payload and battery limitations.

**Micro-robotics:** RoboBee is a tiny robot capable of partially untethered flight developed by Harvard University, with a 3-centimeter wingspan making it the smallest man-made device modeled on an insect to achieve flight.

Links: [{"title":"Robotic mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_mapping"},{"title":"Simultaneous localization and mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simultaneous_localization_and_mapping"},{"title":"Exploration problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exploration_problem"},{"title":"Occupancy grid mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occupancy_grid_mapping"},{"title":"IISc Guidance, Control and Decision Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_Robotics_Laboratory_at_IISc"},{"title":"Gaia Blu - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaia_Blu"},{"title":"Singular matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singular_matrix"},{"title":"Business process automation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business_Process_Automation"},{"title":"Serial manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serial_manipulator"},{"title":"3D Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3D_Robotics"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about robotic mapping:

## Overview

Robotic mapping is a discipline related to computer vision and cartography.(no content)The goal for an autonomous robot is to be able to construct (or use) a map (outdoor use) or floor plan (indoor use) and to localize itself and its recharging bases or beacons in it.

## Key Components

**Sensors**: The sensors of the robot can include a camera, a microphone, laser, lidar, or sonar. Additionally, 3-dimensional models of a robot's environment can be generated using range imaging sensors or 3D scanners.

**Map Representations**: The metric framework is the most common for humans and considers a two-dimensional space in which it places the objects. The topological framework only considers places and relations between them.

## Core Challenge: SLAM

A critical challenge in robotic mapping is Simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM), which is the computational problem of constructing or updating a map of an unknown environment while simultaneously keeping track of an agent's location within it.

## Applications

The exploration problem arises in robotic mapping and search & rescue situations, where an environment might be dangerous or inaccessible to humans.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Simultaneous Localization and Mapping:

## Definition and Overview

Simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) is the computational problem of constructing or updating a map of an unknown environment while simultaneously keeping track of an agent's location within it.

## Problem and Solutions

There are several algorithms known to solve it in, at least approximately, tractable time for certain environments.(no content)Popular approximate solution methods include the particle filter, extended Kalman filter, covariance intersection, and GraphSLAM.

## Applications

SLAM algorithms are based on concepts in computational geometry and computer vision, and are used in robot navigation, robotic mapping and odometry for virtual reality or augmented reality.(no content)Published approaches are employed in self-driving cars, unmanned aerial vehicles, autonomous underwater vehicles, planetary rovers, newer domestic robots and even inside the human body.

## Sensor Types

SLAM will always use several different types of sensors. Optical sensors may be one-dimensional (single beam) or 2D- (sweeping) laser rangefinders, 3D high definition light detection and ranging (lidar), 3D flash lidar, 2D or 3D sonar sensors, and one or more 2D cameras.(no content)Recent forms of SLAM include tactile SLAM (sensing by local touch only), radar SLAM, acoustic SLAM, and Wi-Fi-SLAM (sensing by strengths of nearby Wi-Fi access points).

## Historical Background

A seminal work in SLAM is the research of Smith and Cheeseman on the representation and estimation of spatial uncertainty in 1986. Other pioneering work in this field was conducted by the research group of Hugh F. Durrant-Whyte in the early 1990s.

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of computer vision:

## Overview

Computer vision is a scientific discipline concerned with the theory behind artificial systems that extract information from images.(no content)Computer vision tasks include methods for acquiring, processing, analyzing, and understanding digital images, and extraction of high-dimensional data from the real world in order to produce numerical or symbolic information, e.g. in the form of decisions.

## Key Aspects

"Understanding" in this context signifies the transformation of visual images into descriptions of the world that make sense to thought processes and can elicit appropriate action. This image understanding can be seen as the disentangling of symbolic information from image data using models constructed with the aid of geometry, physics, statistics, and learning theory.

## Data Forms

Image data can take many forms, such as video sequences, views from multiple cameras, multi-dimensional data from a 3D scanner, 3D point clouds from LiDaR sensors, or medical scanning devices.

## Subdisciplines

Subdisciplines of computer vision include scene reconstruction, object detection, event detection, activity recognition, video tracking, object recognition, 3D pose estimation, learning, indexing, motion estimation, visual servoing, 3D scene modeling, and image restoration.

## Modern Developments

The advancement of Deep Learning techniques has brought further life to the field of computer vision.

Links: [{"title":"Sensor fusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensor_fusion"},{"title":"Data fusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_fusion"},{"title":"Multi-focus image fusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-focus_image_fusion"},{"title":"MEMS sensor generations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MEMS_sensor_generations"},{"title":"Fusion frame - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fusion_frame"},{"title":"Shimshon Belkin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shimshon_Belkin"}]

Here's what I found about sensor fusion:

## Definition

Sensor fusion is a process of combining sensor data or data derived from disparate sources so that the resulting information has less uncertainty than would be possible if these sources were used individually.

## Configuration Types

Sensor fusion systems can be organized in several ways:

- **Centralized vs. Decentralized**: In centralized fusion, the clients simply forward all of the data to a central location, and some entity at the central location is responsible for correlating and fusing the data.(no content)In decentralized, the clients take full responsibility for fusing the data.

- **Redundant Configuration**: Sensors are in redundant (or competitive) configuration if each node delivers independent measures of the same properties. This configuration can be used in error correction when comparing information from multiple nodes.

- **Complementary Configuration**: Complementary configuration occurs when multiple information sources supply different information about the same features. This strategy is used for fusing information at raw data level within decision-making algorithms.

- **Cooperative Fusion**: Cooperative sensor fusion uses the information extracted by multiple independent sensors to provide information that would not be available from single sensors.

## Fusion Levels

Data level (or early) fusion aims to fuse raw data from multiple sources and represent the fusion technique at the lowest level of abstraction. It is the most common sensor fusion technique in many fields of application. Data level fusion algorithms usually aim to combine multiple homogeneous sources of sensory data to achieve more accurate and synthetic readings.

## Swarm Robotics Overview

### Definition and Principles

I've performed a web search for "Path planning" and found comprehensive information on this topic. Here's an overview of what path planning is:

## Definition and Overview

Path planning, also known as motion planning (the navigation problem or the piano mover's problem), is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves the object from the source to destination.(no content)The term is used in computational geometry, computer animation, robotics and computer games.

## Applications

For example, consider navigating a mobile robot inside a building to a distant waypoint. It should execute this task while avoiding walls and not falling down stairs. A motion planning algorithm would take a description of these tasks as input, and produce the speed and turning commands sent to the robot's wheels.

## Key Approaches

There are several main categories of path planning algorithms:

- **Any-angle path planning**: Any-angle path planning algorithms are pathfinding algorithms that search for a Euclidean shortest path between two points on a grid map while allowing the turns in the path to have any angle. The result is a path that cuts directly through open areas and has relatively few turns.

- **Real-time path planning**: Real-Time Path Planning is a term used in robotics that consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real time changes in the environment. This includes everything from primitive algorithms that stop a robot when it approaches an obstacle to more complex algorithms that continuously takes in information from the surroundings and creates a plan to avoid obstacles.

- **Multi-agent pathfinding**: The problem of Multi-Agent Pathfinding (MAPF) consists in the computation of collision-free paths for a group of agents from their location to an assigned target.

I've completed a web search for "Mobile robot." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

A mobile robot is an automatic machine that is capable of locomotion.(no content)Mobile robots have the capability to move around in their environment and are not fixed to one physical location.(no content)Mobile robotics is usually considered to be a subfield of robotics and information engineering.

## Applications

Mobile robots have diverse real-world applications:
- Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years.
- Warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.
- Mobile robots are also found in industrial, military and security settings.

## Components

The components of a mobile robot are a controller, sensors, actuators and power system.(no content)The controller is generally a microprocessor, embedded microcontroller or a personal computer (PC).

## Research Focus

Mobile robots are also a major focus of current research and almost every major university has one or more labs that focus on mobile robot research.

I've successfully performed a web search for "Machine learning". Here are the key findings:

## Overview of Machine Learning

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Applications

ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

## Learning Paradigms

Machine learning is commonly separated into three main learning paradigms, supervised learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.

## Key Historical Milestone

The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence.(no content)The earliest machine learning program was introduced in the 1950s when Arthur Samuel invented a computer program that calculated the winning chance in checkers for each side.

## Recent Advances

Within a subdiscipline in machine learning, advances in the field of deep learning have allowed neural networks, a class of statistical algorithms, to surpass many previous machine learning approaches in performance.

The search results provide comprehensive information about machine learning fundamentals, history, applications, and modern developments in the field.

Web search results for query: "Multi-agent system"

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Talk:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Template:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about multi-agent systems:

## Definition

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.

## Purpose and Capabilities

Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous, and there is decentralization where no agent is designated as controlling.(no content)Multi-agent systems can manifest self-organisation as well as self-direction and other control paradigms and related complex behaviors even when the individual strategies of all their agents are simple.

## Components

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment.(no content)The agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"History of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicles in the United States military - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicles_in_the_United_States_military"},{"title":"412th Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Regiment (Ukraine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/412th_Unmanned_Aerial_Vehicle_Regiment_(Ukraine)"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle applications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle_applications"},{"title":"Uncrewed vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_vehicle"},{"title":"Category:Unmanned aerial vehicle manufacturers of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Unmanned_aerial_vehicle_manufacturers_of_the_United_States"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle-related incidents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle-related_incidents"}]

I've completed the web search for "Unmanned aerial vehicle." Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Definition

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## Historical Development

UAVs were originally developed through the twentieth century for military missions.(no content)The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with a balloon carrier in the first offensive use of air power in naval aviation when Austrian forces besieging Venice attempted to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.

## Modern Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications. Applications include aerial photography, search and rescue, power line and pipeline inspection, agriculture, and wildlife counting.

## Consumer Market Growth

In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, laying out legal groundwork for consumer drone usage inside the United States.(no content)In 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone, an entry-level drone priced at $629 that was considered one of the most influential consumer drone products ever made.

Here are the search results for "Control theory":

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Historical Development

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)Although the most direct application of mathematical control theory is its use in control systems engineering, control theory is routinely applied to problems in both the natural and behavioral sciences. As the general theory of feedback systems, control theory is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

message_text: Good! Now let me run the validation script:

message_metadata.text_block: Good! Now let me run the validation script:

content.text: Good! Now let me run the validation script:

purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as 'contribution' or 'survey'. Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence explaining why it matters)

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Collaborative Multi-Robot Search and Rescue: Planning, Coordination, Perception, and Active Vision." Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** `survey` - This is a literature review/survey paper that reviews existing multi-robot systems and approaches for search and rescue operations.

**Triples Extracted:** 17 key entities with proper categorization

**Entity Distribution:**
- 4 Tasks (Search and rescue, Robot navigation, Robotic mapping, Motion planning)
- 4 Artifacts (Autonomous robot, Unmanned aerial vehicle, Mobile robot, Autonomous underwater vehicle)
- 5 Concepts (Multi-agent system, Active vision, Swarm robotics, Control theory, and additional multi-agent system)
- 2 Methods (Simultaneous localization and mapping, Sensor fusion)
- 2 Tools (Computer vision, Machine learning)

**Key Technologies Identified:**
1. **Search and rescue** - The primary task being surveyed
2. **Autonomous robots and UAVs** - Different types of physical systems discussed
3. **SLAM and robotic mapping** - Core navigation and mapping capabilities
4. **Active vision and computer vision** - Perception technologies
5. **Multi-agent systems and swarm robotics** - Coordination approaches
6. **Control theory and machine learning** - Theoretical frameworks

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the validation passed successfully, confirming that the triples are properly formatted and reference valid Wikipedia articles.

Sources:
- [Search and rescue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_and_rescue)
- [Autonomous robot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot)
- [Multi-agent system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system)
- [Robot navigation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation)
- [Robotic mapping](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_mapping)
- [Simultaneous localization and mapping](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simultaneous_localization_and_mapping)
- [Active vision](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_vision)
- [Computer vision](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_vision)
- [Sensor fusion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensor_fusion)
- [Motion planning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning)
- [Unmanned aerial vehicle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle)
- [Mobile robot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot)
- [Autonomous underwater vehicle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_underwater_vehicle)
- [Swarm robotics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics)
- [Control theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory)
- [Machine learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning)
